title: coronavirus leader of the opposition ask difficult questions
story: THESE are pretty grim times. For those of you who say this virus is nothing out of the ordinary, a big fuss about nothing – how often do we have a Prime Minister in intensive care We all wish Boris a swt recovery. The country needs a strong leader at a time like this and Boris has proved, in three short months, he is that leader.There have been calls for a national unity government. All the parties coming together to see us through this crisis. It’s happened before, of course — most famously during World War Two, when we had a coalition government led by Boris’s hero, Sir Winston Churchill. We had one during the Napoleonic Wars back in , too, when that short French tosser was causing havoc in Europe.But do we need one now I think not. The only reason people are raising the issue now is because the Labour Party at last has a leader who isn’t actually certiable.Nobody would seriously think that giving power to an oaf like Jeremy Corbyn would help us through this crisis.But there are plenty of other reasons to object. First of all, we kind of already have a unity government.The Conservatives have a whopping -seat majority. In the last opinion poll Boris had  per cent of the country behind him, thinking he was doing a good job. That’s about as close to unanimous as you will ever get in a democracy. The Government, then, has a free hand.Perhapsthis virus had struck back in October last year, there might have been a point. Then we had a paralysed government with no working majority.Battling this virus would have been nigh on impossible in such a position. But the December General Election changed all that.But then there’s this. Unity governments are usually convened when we are threatened by a foreign power — as happened in World Wars One and Two and indeed the Napoleonic Wars. There have been brief exceptions.But by and large we have a unity government to show the foreign power that the whole country is united. The virus isn’t a ­foreign power. It is an insentient microscopic parasite. It doesn’t give a monkey’s who is running the country.But the most important objection is this. We are a democracy. And democracy is no less important during times of crisis than at other times. And we need a competent opposition to hold the Government to account. Boris and co haven’t done a bad job, so far. But there are plenty of questions that could be asked. Did the Government react too slowly  Why do our frontline medical staff not have adequate protection against the virus  Why did we allow planes to land from China, back in March, when the danger was apparent.OK, you may think some of those questions unfair. And asked with the benefit of hindsight. But it is the job of the Opposition to ask dficult questions, to challenge policies and highlight incompetency.I would argue that is more vital now than at any time in the last  years.Labour’s new leader, Sir Keir Starmer appears to be a sensible bloke.He is generally behind the Government in its fight against this pandemic.But he must be allowed to question, in public, the Government’s policies.We are no less unied when dficult questions are asked of politicians.The more those dficult questions are asked, the quicker this virus will be beaten.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealLIFE will never be the same again. No, I’m not talking about this wretched virus for once.The Labour Party has got rid of almost all of its nutters from positions of influence.Diane Abbott has gone. John McDonnell has gone.So has the former chairman, the godawful Geordie Ian Lavery.Corbyn himself will be gone very soon.What are we going to do for a laugh without these clowns spouting rubbish all day long Luckily — thank the Lord! — the genuinely berserk David Lammy has been installed as Shadow Justice Secretary.It’s up to you, now David, you dingbat. Keep us chuckl­ing during these dark days.DONALD Trump has turned his guns on the World Health Organisation.He’s threatened to cut off its funding. He reckons the WHO has handled the virus pandemic very badly.The WHO told Trump he was wrong to ban flights from China at the start of the outbreak because it “wasn’t necessary”.He said: “The WHO receives vast amounts of money from the United States and we pay for a majority, the biggest portion of their money, and they actually criticised and disagreed with my travel ban at the time I did it.“And they were wrong. They’ve been wrong about a lot of things.”He may look like a morbidly obese Belisha beacon in a badly fitting wig.He may sometimes talk out of his a***hole. He may have the diplomatic abilities of a semi-housetrained wolverine.But he may well be dead right on this.SOME experts reckon we could be in a state of lockdown until well into autumn.That sounds pretty grim. story: The PM has not been able to contact to Ms Symonds who is only weeks away from giving birth to their first child.Mr Johnson is still in intensive care with coronavirus but is sitting up and engaging positively with his medical team, Chancellor Rishi Sunak said yesterday.No said the PM continues to make steady progress and is able to contact people he needs to.A spokesman said: He said: The PM is not working, hes in intensive care, he has the ability to contact those that he needs to, hes following the advice of his doctors at all times.Friends of Ms Symonds said she was distraught when he was admitted to hospital and she was self-isolating with symptoms of COVID-.One cabinet minister said she was the only one in Downing street who cares about his welfare.Ms Symonds wrote on Twitter that she was feeling stronger and on the mend after a week in bed with symptoms of coronavirus.She added it was obviously worrying being pregnant while suffering symptoms.Mr Johnson was taken to St Thomas Hospital on Sunday, and transferred to the ICU on Monday evening after his condition deteriorated.He was given standard oxygen treatment but had not required ventilation and was not diagnosed with pneumonia.The PM tried to keep up appearances for the country by having his parliamentary red boxes delivered to hospital, but handed the reigns of the Government over to Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab earlier this week.Mr Sunak said yesterday: The latest from the hospital is the Prime Minister remains in intensive care where his condition is improving.I can also tell you that he has been sitting up in bed and engaging positively with the clinical team.He added: The Prime Minister is not only my colleague and my boss but also my friend, and my thoughts are with him and his family. The news about the PM reminds us how indiscriminate this disease is.It could still be a long road to recovery for Mr Johnson once he does get better from the deadly virus, and is let out of hospital.People around the country gathered on Tuesday night to clap for Mr Johnson and wish him a speedy recovery.The spokesman for No said: We are hugely grateful for the messages of support that the Prime Minister has received.Intensive care consultant at Imperial College London told BBC Radio : When you are seriously ill it does take time to recover.Its not an all-or-nothing thing... but it can take many weeks to get back to normal full health or even months.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: five children teens england coronavirus
story: FIVE teenagers and children and nearly  other people aged under  have died in England after contracting coronavirus, new figures show.At least , of , people who died with the disease were aged  or over, NHS England statistics published yesterday revealed.Another , people who died were aged -, with  Covid- deaths among people aged -.Forty-seven of the deaths were among Brits aged -.Yesterday, the UK surpassed coronavirus-ravaged Italys deadliest day after  Brits died from the disease - taking the grim total to over ,.Positive cases in the UK have also hit , - up from , infections in  hours.Experts are trying to determine why some younger people with no known underlying health issues are dying from the disease.Older people are more at risk but the World Health Organisation has warned younger people are not invincible.Underlying health conditions are also a factor, regardless of a persons age.Yesterdays shocking statistics include Britains youngest known victim, a five-year-old child who had underlying health conditions.Another young Brit, -year-old Ismail Mohamed Abdulwahab, died in Kings College Hospital in London last Monday after testing positive for the deadly disease.His mum and six siblings were not able to be by his side in his final moments in case they too caught the killer virus.The heartbroken family have now paid tribute to the teenager, saying: We are heartbroken as a family due to the devastation caused by the coronavirus as it becomes too real for us as a family and community.Ismail was a loving son, brother, nephew to our family and a friend to many people who knew him. His smile was heart-warming and he was always gentle and kind.The teenagers family, from Brixton South London couldnt attend his funeral as two of his siblings had developed symptoms.Strangers in protective suits and masks carried his coffin and placed it into a grave.An extremely healthy -year-old chef from Italy died in London from the bug.Luca Di Nicola,  is said to have had no underlying health conditions.A person aged  is believed to be the oldest UK victim to die with coronavirus.Research by Imperial College London shows  per cent of under-s hospitalised with the virus need critical care,  compared to  per cent of those in their s and  per cent of people in their s.Virologist Michael Skinner, from Imperial College London, told : It is very possible that some of us could have a particular genetic makeup that makes it more likely that we will respond badly to an infection with this coronavirus.Other scientists think the level of the bug someone is infected with is key.Research from Imperial College London shows  five per scent of under-s  need to be hospitalised with coronavirus symptoms, with the figure rising to  per cent for --year-oldsTwo huge temporary morgues have been built in London to bury bodiesdeaths spike,An emergency mortuary with initial space for , bodies has also been set up at Birmingham Airport and another in Cambridge to cope with a surge in fatalities.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tearful girl after mum loses job coronavirus
story: A TEARFUL schoolgirl has begged for “things to go back to normal” in an emotional video after her mum lost her job because of the coronavirus crisis.Madison Williams, , from Derbyshire, broke down in tears as she admitted her mum Alexandra, , wasn’t “earning any money”.The youngster recorded her plea for support on her mum’s phone after both her parents lost their jobs.In the clip, later shared on Twitter, she says: “I am really scared and worried because at the minute loads of people in my country and other countries have coronavirus, more than ,, and its just really scary.“My mum doesnt have a job at the minute and shes not earning any money, and my dads works shut down so hes not earning any money”.Madison adds: If anyones seen this that has kids or is a parent to a young child, I really need your help by saying that well get through together because I dont think its fair on any parent that cant go to work or is losing their job because of this.“Theyve worked so hard for their career and stuff. And theyre not going to be getting any money so they really wont be able to pay like, the water, the bills, the gas, the electric, and thats quite a bit of money.“So please,anyone sees this, help us out and do us a favour. I really just hope everything goes back to normal soon.”Madison also said she can’t wait to get back to school because she misses her friends.The school girl tells the camera: “Its my last year at primary school and this is not how I want to end it.“So please, make everything go back to normal, Boris. We believe in you.”Madison’s mum Alexandra works in telesales but was left in dire straits after being told by her boss she did not qualy for furlough pay.She broke down when she found the clip on her phone and shared it on Twitter to support the #newstarterfurlough campaign.The movement wants Chancellor Rishi Sunak to allow those who started jobs after February  to qualy for furlough pay.She tweeted: “I cant speak at the minute. I have just found this on her phone after having to comfort her, to get to sleep. I feel sick to my stomach. I am now on my knees begging. She is petried.”The mum later told MailOnline: “I thought she was coping so much better. [She was] bottling everything up. When I found this I dont think I have ever cried so much.”Alexandra said she is now so hard-up that she can’t even afford to buy her kids easter eggs.She said: “I went back to my old employer who said he wished he could help me - I truly believe that too - but he told me he could only take me back onI had been made redundant due to Covid-, which I wasnt. I will never forget that moment.“In all honesty, I dont want benefits. I have never claimed in my le. I dont want to start now. I just want my job back”.A government spokesperson said it is up to inidual firmsthey want to pay an employee furlough pay.They explained: “The Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme is aimed at those who would otherwise be unemployed as a result of coronavirus.“It allows for those who were on the payroll of a company on  February but subsequently left to be put back on payroll and furloughed.“Decisions around whether to offer to furlough someone are down to the inidual company.”

title: mps extra cash expenses work home coronavirus
story: The Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority has issued updated guidance which states every MP can access the additional cash to boost their office budget to pay for things like laptops for staff and electricity.In addition, the monthly credit limit for MPs has been increased to £,, a  day limit on expenses claims has been suspended and rules on the evidence needed for costs to be reimbursed have been relaxed.The move by the expenses watchdog has been described as crude by critics amid concerns that the updated system and extra cash could be open to abuse.Sir Alistair Graham, a former chairman of the committee on standards in public le, hit out at the decision and said: It seems to me a very crude approach.I think the public may be slightly puzzled as to why what looks like a generous payment of this nature has been made without first doing a bit more research into what the actual costs are.And James Roberts, political director of the Taxpayers Alliance, said: While its reasonable for MPs staff to have access to the equipment they need to work from home during this crisis, politicians should take care to use the cash properly and avoid it being seen as a personal equipment slush fund.But parliamentary staffers hit back at the criticism, saying it enabled them to work from home during the crisis.Alice Hopkins, a Conservative Parliamentary worker tweeted: “MPs  staff based in Westminster need Parliament IT equipment to be able to do their work securely from home.”She added that “not a penny will go to MPs” but the backlash was filling staffers inboxes with “ill informed emails distracting us from emergency casework.”She added: “My bosses  colleagues are working round the clock everyday to help s of constituents getting in touch.“The people who are furious that we can work securely at home will also expect immediate helpthey asked.”The guidance, published last month, reads: This is an uncertain and challenging time. Ipsa is committed to supporting MPs and their staff to carry on with their work as far as possible.In a letter to MPs, Richard Lloyd, the interim chairman of Ipsa, wrote: We have agreed a series of immediate measures that we hope will provide you with the resources and flexibility to concentrate on your parliamentary duties and support your staff.Minister James Cleverly added after the story that he would like to publicly thank my teamfor the work that they are doing.I know they aren’t the only ones having a tough time but we MPs couldn’t help our constituents properly without them.They are helping and working with worried, often vulnerable people on my behalf, who are themselves dealing with unprecedented situations. They are researching, collating, and passing on advice and guidance in a fast changing environment.The volume of work has, understandably, increased over the last few weeks and they are working through it with all the additional challenges of working remotely.If things are a bit slower than usual, please bear with us as we navigate these uncharted waters. So to my team I say “thank you”.Labour staffer Amelia-Rose Tighe added: I’ve had to procure secure laptops for staff to work at home.We have never had as many vulnerable people contact us needing help.Anyone bashing this- are you expecting staff to travel to work to help constituents or should we just ignore them This money does NOT go in MPs pockets as the headline suggests, it goes into a budget to be spent on running an office. title: china dogs companions new guidelines animal trade
story: The announcement by the Ministry of Agriculture was described as a potential game changer in animal welfare.Even though dog meat remains a delicacy in many Chinese regions, the notice published yesterday made it clear that hounds would no longer be considered as livestock.The notice by the agriculture ministry said: As far as dogs are concerned, along with the progress of human civilisation and the public concern and love for animal protection, dogs have been specialised to become companion animals, and internationally are not considered to be livestock, and they will not be regulated as livestock in China.The word livestock is used to refer to a category of animals that can be bred to provide food, milk, fur, fibre and medicine or to serve the needs of sports or the military.The new coronavirus, which is believed to have originated from horseshoe bats, put a spotlight on Chinas wild animal trade.COVID- - which was first identied in the Chinese city of Wuhan - could have been passed onto humans by intermediary species on sale at a wet market.Those markets, where wild and often poached animals are packed together, have been described as a breeding ground for disease and an incubator for a multitude of viruses to evolve.Following the outbreak of the virus, China banned the breeding, trading and consumption of wildle - revoking all existing licenses.It also promised to revise legislation to make the ban permanent.The draft guidelines published yesterday - which have been opened to the public for consultation - listed  traditional livestock species, including cattle, pigs, poultry and camels.The notice also added  special species that would also be exempt from wild animal trading restrictions, including reindeer, alpaca, pheasants, ostriches and foxes.Dog consumption has become increasingly unpopular in China and the southern city of Shenzhen became the first to ban it last month.However, the Humane Society International, an animal welfare group, estimated that around  million dogs a year are still killed in China for meat, including stolen pets.The city of Yulin in the region of Guangxi holds an annual dog meat festival in June.There, stray dogs or stolen pet dogs are trapped in tiny cages where they cannot breathe or even stand up properly.The animals are then transported to a slaughterhouse in Yulin, south-west China.Charity Humane Society International has said that as many as  dogs are killed at the abattoir every day.Wendy Higgins, a Humane Society International spokeswoman, said: This draft proposal could signal a game-changer moment for animal protection in China.

title: change health conditions lockdown twice
story: A NEW change in lockdown rules means people with health conditions can now leave home twice a day.It comes after a legal discussion between Public Health England and a firm representing two autistic children who need to leave twice for their health.Now those with health conditions which require them to leave home more than once a day will be allowed to do so.The updated guidance now reads: You can leave your home for medical need.If youhave a specic health condition that requires you to leave the home to maintain your health - includingthat involves travel beyond your local area - then you can do so.This could, for example, include where iniduals with learning disabilities or autism require specic exercise in an open space two or three times each day - ideally in line with a care plan agreed with a medical professional.Before the change Brits were only allowed to leave their homes once a day and not allowed to travel signicant distances.It comes after Birdmans LLP law firm was asked to help by two families with children on the autistic spectrum.The firm explained: One child in particular is deliberately taken to a quiet location that is not local to them, because of their particular needs and where there is a far more limited risk of infectionthanhe were to remain in an urban environment.It was submitted that adults and children with certain health conditionswere disproportionately impacted by the inflexible policy which required everyone to only leave the house for exercise once per day, and which was therefore unlawful and discriminatory.After the change, a spokesperson for the Cabinet Office said: “The single most important action we can all take, in fighting coronavirus, is to stay at home in order to save lives, protect the vulnerable and protect the NHS.“We understand that this will be more dficult for some, that’s why we claried the guidance regarding the needs of those with specic health conditions such as learning disabilities or autism.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal

title: uk lockdown dominic raab too early
story: IT IS too early to lt the coronvirus lockdown measures right now and Brits must stay home this Easter bank holiday weekend, Dominic Raab said tonight.The Foreign Secretary, who is standing in for Boris while hes in hospital, apologised to the nation that they will be unable to see their families this weekend as part of the fight to stop the virus.And he took the chance to thank everyone for their hard work so far in staying home to save lives.He told the public ahead of a sunny weekend: It is too early to lt the measures we have put in place.We must stick to the plan and continue to be guided by the science.Thank you for your sacrice but we are not done yet. We must keep going.No easing of the lockdown will happen until at least the end of next week, he said - but will likely continue for even longer.Professor Chris Whitty said he would expect the number of deaths to continue rising for two weeks past when the number of people in intensive care starts to flatten off.Mr Raab urged anyone considering breaking the rules in the coming days to think very hard about those who were on the front line battling the virus.He would usually be spending the bank holiday with his family but admitted we just cant do those sorts of things, and I am really sorry about that.As a country we need to be united in this mission.We have to keep it up.Mr Raab admitted tonight that he hasnt spoken to Boris Johnson since he went into hospital, and was rushed into intensive care on Monday evening.He said it was important to give him time to rest and recover, and stressed I’ve got all the authority I need to make the relevant decisions.That will include huge decisions on extending the lockdown next week,the PM isnt well enough by then.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what are asian hornets sting
story: Asian hornets, which have the Latin name Vespa velutina, are large insects that prey on smaller creatures, especially bees.Experts are worried the hornets could have a devastating impact on Britains already dwindling honey bee population.Asian hornets look similar to native European hornets but with darker colouring.Queens grow up to cm in , and workers up to .cm.Their bodies are dark brown or black, and bordered with a yellow band, while they have one band across the abdomen.Their legs are brown with yellow ends and they have an orange face.Asian hornets arrived in France inside Chinese pot plants in  and are increasingly common across the Channel.Since then British beekeepers have been sent warnings by the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs.Wildle experts warned it was just a matter of time before Asian hornets appear in Britain to threaten the beleaguered bee population.Nicola Spence, Defra Deputy Director for Plant and Bee Health, said: We have been anticipating the arrival of the Asian hornet for some years and have a well-established protocol in place to eradicate them and control any potential spread.It is important to remember they pose no greater risk to human health than a bee, though we recognise the damage they can cause to honey bee colonies. Thats why we are taking swt and robust action to identy and destroy any nests.We remain vigilant across the country, working closely with the National Bee Unit and their nationwide network of bee inspectors.Asian hornets contain a neurotoxin that can kill in just a single sting.The sting also holds eight chemicals that can cause an allergic shock in humans. In France, six people have already died from anaphylactic shock after being stung.Concern has also been raised about the potential arrival of the Asian hornet in the UK because the beasts are known to attack honey bees, whose numbers already dwindling.There are now just  native species of honey bee in the UK and numbers may be as low as , at the height of summer.Some experts believe the hornets eat as many as  bees a day and government officials are already coming up with plans to combat the arrival of the killer Asian hornet on our shores.The hornets have jaws strong enough to chew through protective bee clothing and feed them to larvae.What happensyou spot them The Asian hornet is a day-flying species which, unlike the European hornet, ceases activity at dusk.It nests in tall trees in urban and rural areas, and nests can also be found in sheds, garages, under decking or in holes in the wall or ground.Disturbing a hornets’ nest can be extremely dangerous as up to  insects will join in an attack on any perceived threat.Dont run.They can fly faster than you can run and are intrigued by moving targets and consider running a provocation. Crouch low to the ground, stop moving and try to cover your head.Sightings should be sent with a photograph and location.You can also email apha.corporatecorrespondence@apha.gsi.gov.uk. title: hay fever pollen bomb symptoms
story: Warm weather and spells of sunshine are always welcomed but it can also cause a huge surge in pollen levels hitting sufferers hard. We reveal all...According to the New Scientist, plants need a period of cold then warm weather before they can flower.Butthere is a long winter, plants that couldnt flower earlier in the spring are more likely to do so all at once.The term is known as a condensed spring because it is far shorter than normal.This causes more pollen to be produced - causing misery for hayfever sufferers.Tree pollen is likely to be worse, which affects one in four Brits.In short - yes.The Met Office has predicted high pollen levels across most of England, except the North East, as well as all of Wales.Scotland and Northern Ireland are set to see medium levels, with only Orkney and Shetland set to escape the pollen bomb.Those conditions are predicted to stay pretty much the same for most of July.Sufferers will experience cold-like symptoms - such as itchy eyes and a runny nose - but the threat could be more serious.Half of Brits plagued by hay fever could experience deadly asthma attacks triggered by the pollen.Hay fever and asthma are closely linked, with around  per cent of people with asthma finding their symptoms are made worse when pollen counts are high.You can check pollen levels on the Met Office website.Sonia Munde, nurse manager at Asthma UK, said anyone who has both asthma and hay fever should ensure they are taking antihistamines and nasal steroid sprays, and ensure they take their preventer inhaler as prescribed to ward off an attack.She added: Pollen is a top trigger for asthma attacks at this time of the year, affecting an estimated .million people with asthma in the UK.People with asthma who also have a pollen allergy not only experience classic hay fever symptoms such as itchy eyes and a running nose, but are also at an increased risk of a le-threatening asthma attack.Holly Shaw, nurse adviser at Allergy UK, urged people to stock up on antihistamines to help manage their symptoms.Typically the hay fever season starts in mid-March, with tree pollen blooming until May.However, the damp weather in June  meant there was a delay to the pollen season this year but pollen levels are expected to be high in the early part of July, causing problems for hay fever sufferers.With wet conditions a lot of the pollen in the air is simply washed away.Dr Beverley Adams-Groom told the Mail: The weather in most of June was pretty poor which meant quite a lot of pollen was washed away by the rain.But the past week or so has been nicer so we’ve started to see high or very high counts again.While normally we’d be past the main peak by now we’ve had something of a delayed pollen season this year.With last year’s hot, dry conditions, grass was dry and exhausted by the start of July.Instead this year’s wet June means it’s still growing so pollen is still being expelled, meaning it will be a longer season this year.Allergy expert Max Wiseberg warned: “When the tree pollen season is delayed, more trees are likely to release their pollen at the same time, creating a time bomb waiting to explode.“Peaks of tree pollen could be higher than normal.The recent cold wintry weather provided the optimum conditions for this to happen.”Our title: coronavirus pressure priti patel after
story: NewsCoronavirus: Pressure on Priti Patel after Home Office staff told toto workThe Home Secretary faces questions after Passport Office workers were reportedly told Covid- will infect % of people and we cant hide away from it foreverShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  APR News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Priti Patel faces questions after Home Office staff were told toto work despite the coronavirus lockdown.A scientic advisor to the department reportedly told staff % of people would get Covid- in the end, and that “we can’t hide away from it forever. A leaked transcript of a Zoom meeting involving Passport Office managers, reported by the BBC, suggested up to , members of staff couldto work on routine passport applications. According to the transcript Home Office deputy scientic adviser, Rupert Shute, told the meeting: “You are no more at risk at the workplace as you would be in your home or at the supermarket. It is about minimising it.” He reportedly added: “We are working on the assessment that % of us,we havenapost already, will get the virus. We cannot hide away from it forever. Mark Serwotka, general secretary of the PCS Union said: “It is absolutely scandalous that HMPO are suggesting our members can go back into work during a pandemic to process routine passports. The cavalier approach to our membersapos health and safety is shameful and ultimately puts them in greater danger of contracting Covid-. We have already had members die as a result of contracting corona and pressured civil service managers in other departments to shut offices so staff can work from home. For the deputy chief scientic adviser at the Home Office to suggest that going into work does not put you at greater risk of contracting corona is extremely irresponsible and totally contradicts current Government guidance. Processing passports is not critical work while we are in lockdown and international travel is practically non-existent due to the corona pandemic. A Home Office spokesman said: Her Majestyaposs Passport Office is fully adhering to public health advice across all our offices and adopting social distancing measures to keep both its staff and customers safe. It continues to operate at substantially restricted staffing levels with a signicant number of people working from home where possible, and staff are prioritising emergency cases. Guidance is also available for people who are travelling into work. It was made clear in the meeting that the Governmentaposs priority is slowing the spread of coronavirus and we all have a part to play in order to protect the NHS and save lives.  The Home Office added that Government advice has been clear that people may travel for work purposes,they cannot work from home. At a Number  briefing this morning, the Prime Minister’s official spokesman said: “I think the government advice is very clear that you may travel for work purposesyou cannot work from home. “That guidance is obviously available for the passport staff who are travelling into work.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Dominic Raab looks set to make any decisions around extending the UK lockdown while Boris Johnson remains in intensive care.Downing Street said today it was clear the Prime Minister is not working and decisions in his absence will be taken by the First Secretary of State. The statement shows the extent to which Mr Raab has taken over his bossaposs duties while Mr Johnson is in St Thomasapos Hospital. In a noon update today after his third night in intensive care, No said: The Prime Minister had a good night and continues to improve in intensive care at St Thomas’ Hospital. He is in good spirits.” He is still receiving “standard oxygen treatment” and is “able to contact peoplerequired”, though his aides did not say how orhe is using a phone.  Downing Street all but guaranteed the lockdown will be extended beyond April . But No appeared to suggest it wonapost be made stricter for the moment, despite fears about people breaking the rules over a warm Easter weekend. Askednew measures are on the agenda, Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman said: The focus for now is on ensuring people continue to stick by measures which we’ve put in place. “The public response has been brilliant. People have made very big sacrices.”  The governmentaposs emergency committee will meet at .pm as it kicks off discussions over where next to go with the UKaposs nationwide lockdown.Mr Raab will chair talks with the Scottish, Welsh and Northern Irish governments about next steps. Downing Street has refused to say officially that the lockdown will be extended beyond April  - because a formal decision will only be taken next week. But itaposs obvious to virtually everyone that it will be. Wales has already extended its lockdown and Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said today: I don’t think there is any possibility, any likelihood of these lockdown measures being lted immediately or even imminently.  Downing Street and senior ministers signalled clearly that the lockdown will be extended, as has been widely expected for days. Boris Johnson’s spokesman said he was not contradicting Nicola Sturgeon. Regardless of when the legal decision actually happens, the lockdown remains in place until it is lted. Reports today claimed the delay was due to wanting to let Boris Johnson take part in the decision. But the government has insisted itaposs because full evidence will only be available next week.  Askedofficials were hoping to consult Boris Johnson before a decision is taken, the PM’s spokesman said: “The Prime Minister is not working, I think we’re very clear on that. And he has asked the First Secretary of State to deputise. “It will be the First Secretary of State who leads the COBR meeting today and the First Secretary of State who will lead any Cabinet decision-making process. Emergency powers kicked in on March  that ban people going outside without a good reason. Offenders can be fined £ to start with by police, rising to almost £, by a third offence. The law says a Cabinet minister must review the law at least once every three weeks and by April . Asked what the exit plan is for lockdown, Downing Street said the peak of the virus has not even occurred yet. “We need to be focused relentlessly on stopping the transmission of this disease,” Boris Johnson’s spokesman said. Police are gearing up for a dficult Easter weekend as temperatures are set to reach C - tempting more people out of their homes. Northamptonshire Police Chief Constable Nick Adderley warned his force will strengthen the enforcement of the law - and could search shopping trolleys for non-essential items.

story: NewsMatt Hancock faces calls to cancel student debt for nurses tackling coronavirusMore than  Labour MPs have written to the Health Secretary asking for student loans to be forgiven for thousands of nurses who have fast tracked onto the frontlineShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  APR News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Health Secretary Matt Hancock faces calls to cancel student debt for nurses helping to battle coronavirus. More than  Labour MPs joined together asking the government to forgive student loans for nurses fast-tracked to the frontline.Some , students from  universities had signed up for paid placements as of Friday, according to Health Education England figures. These nurses have rearranged their studies in response to a call from Mr Hancock for them to join the NHS frontline a few months before they originally expected to end their studies and qualy. But they will still be liable for £, a year in tuition fees. MPs, led by Luton North MP Sarah Owen, called on the government to “support these new nurses by cancelling the student debt they have incurred throughout their studies.”Ms Owen, who sits on the Commons Health Committee, said: We owe so much to all the doctors, nurses and other health workers who are risking their own health to keep our NHS going and look after our loved ones during this outbreak. “No nurse should have had student debt forced on them - and never have a group of newly qualied nurses faced such a challenging time to join the frontline of the NHS.”

title: uk coronavirus lockdown explained how
story: NewsUK coronavirus lockdown explained - how long will it last and what are the rules Yes, the UK lockdown is going to be extended. No, police cant just fine you for anything. But no, you definitely cant go for a picnic this Easter weekendShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsA police officer speaks to two people sat on the grass in Greenwich Park, London " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UKaposs coronavirus lockdown looks set to be extended as Brits hunker down for the long haul. Drastic limits on leaving your home will be reviewed by April  - but itaposs clear they wonapost be lted. As coronavirus deaths continue to rocket, they will probably drt on into May at least. A meeting of the COBRA emergency committee today kicked off the process of working out what to do next, chaired by Boris Johnsonaposs deputy Dominic Raab.  But the government isnapost planning to actually tighten the law - yet. Instead the focus will be on enforcing the law we already have and making it last longer. Meanwhile police are preparing for a tough Easter weekend - with threats to search peopleaposs shopping and fine anyone going to bask in the sun. So what can and canapost you do under the lockdown law, what is changing, and when will it all end   Hereaposs the lockdown latest explained.What are the basic lockdown rules  You cannot leave the house where you live without reasonable excuse. That boils down to:Shopping for basic necessities, for example food and medicine, which must be as infrequent as possible One form of exercise a day, for example a run, walk, or cycle - alone or with members of your household Any medical need, including to donate blood, avoid or escape risk of injury or harm, or to provide care or to help a vulnerable person Travelling for work purposes, but only where you cannot work from home. Gatherings of more than two people are banned in public - unless youaposre from the same household, or a few other exceptions . And pubs, cafes, restaurants, gyms, funfairs, playgrounds, sports courts, cinemas, theatres, nightclubs, bingo halls, concert halls, museums, galleries, car showrooms, casinos, betting shops, spas, hair and beauty salons, barbers, massage parlours, tattoo studios, skating rinks and more must shut.  What is the punishment for breaking the lockdown  Breaking the rules above without reasonable excuse, or obstructing an officer enforcing them, is a criminal offence and you can be prosecuted. However, you can in most cases avoid a criminal conviction by paying a aposfixed penalty noticeapos issued by the police within  days. The law allows police to issue £ fixed penalty notices - rising to £ for a second offence and then doubling each time up to a cap of £. Police, PCSOs, council officers and other government representatives can also order or force you toto your home, and disperse gatherings of more than two people.  When did the UK go into lockdown - and for how long  The lockdown was announced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Monday  March. It took effect immediately. Police powers to enforce the lockdown took force a few days later - at pm on Thursday  March. The law says the lockdown must be reviewed by Health Secretary Matt Hancock every three weeks, with the first review by Thursday  April. But reviewing the lockdown doesnapost mean it stops. The law is in force for up to six months without the government needing to write a new one. Will the lockdown be extended for longer than three weeks  Yes. The UK government hasnapost made an official announcement because thataposll only come next week. But ministers, civil servants and  Downing Street have been absolutely clear that April  is much too soon to end the lockdown. Wales has already confirmed it will extend the lockdown. Scotlandaposs First Minister Nicola Sturgeon added: I don’t think there is any possibility, any likelihood of these lockdown measures being lted immediately or even imminently. Even before a COBRA meeting to discuss the lockdown, Downing Street basically confirmed the UK government agrees with Ms Sturgeon.  Why isnapost the extension being announced properly today  Because the government wants to wait to see how well the restrictions are working at reducing cases. A formal announcement will be made on or before April , based on scientic evidence. Whoaposll make the decision  Technically itaposs made by Health Secretary Matt Hancock but itaposll be overseen by Boris Johnsonaposs stand-in, Dominic Raab. Not the PM, whoaposs in intensive care. Downing Street said: The Prime Minister is not working. I think weaposre very clear on that. And he has asked the First Secretary of State to deputise for him. It will be the First Secretary of State who leads the COBRA meeting [on Thursday] and the First Secretary of State who will lead any cabinet decision making process.  So can I go out for a picnic this Easter weekend then  No, absolutely not. Yes, the lockdown is being reviewed, but that absolutely does not mean it has stopped. You may only go outside your home with a reasonable excuse - just like any other day under lockdown. When will the lockdown end  We donapost know. But it will only be lted when the UK is well over the peak of new Covid- cases per day, and thataposs not any time soon. Ministers had hoped the peak would be Easter Sunday but estimates now put it at least a week or two later. Even then, cases have to drastically dwindle too. Otherwise thereaposll just be a second outbreak. The UK government has also repeatedly refused to say what its aposexitapos strategy is. Until we get a vaccine next year, itaposs quite possible they just donapost know yet. Officials havenapost ruled out a partial end to the lockdown, where some people can go outside earlier than others. Or restrictions being lted for a few weeks, then reimposed.  Are even stricter restrictions on the way  Not right now, no. The government hasnapost ruled out making the rules even stricter - such as banning exercise. But No emphasised the focus is on policing the current rules more strictly, not making new ones. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman said: I think the focus for now is ensuring that people continue to stick by the measures weaposve put in place. Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden warned the government may enhance or change the lockdown, but thataposs not happening right now. No said: Weaposve always said thatthe scientic advice suggested other steps are needed weaposd be prepared to take them. But for now our focus is on ensuring the steps we already have in place are properly enforced. What does the law actually say  The lockdown is enforced through a law called the Health Protection Regulations . Importantly, it isnapost exactly the same as the government guidance. You should of course follow both, but it makes a dference to whether police can stop you going about your business. Here we go through a few common situations. Whataposs the full list of aposreasonable excusesapos for leaving my house  Reasonable excuses include, but it appears are not limited to:To obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies for those in the same householdor for vulnerable persons To take exercise either alone or with other members of their household To seek medical assistance To provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person, or to provide emergency assistance To donate blood To travel for the purposes of work or to provide voluntary or charitable services, where it is not reasonably possible for that person to work from home To attend a funeral of a member of the person’s household, a close family member, orneither are attending, a friend To fulfil a legal obligation, including attending court or satisfying bail conditions To access critical public services, including childcare school, social services, DWP services, victims of crime services To allow children with shared custody to move between each parentaposs house For a minister of religion, to go to their place of worship To move house where reasonably necessary To avoid injury or illness or to escape a risk of harm.When can more than two people gather in public  Exceptions to the rule are:Where all the people in the gathering are members of the same household Where the gathering is essential for work purposes To attend a funeral To facilitate a house move* To provide emergency assistance* To fulfil a legal obligation* To provide care to a vulnerable person** Where reasonably necessary. Can police fine meI exercise twice in one day  No. Government guidance is clear - you should only exercise once a day. You should follow this advice. But the law itself doesnapost specy how many times you can go out. It just says you may take exerciseyou need to. Meanwhile, guidance has been updated to let people with a medical need go out multiple times a day, for instance people with learning disabilities or autism.  Can police stop me sitting in the park  Yes,you canapost provide a reasonable excuse. You wonapost be surprised to hear the list of possible reasonable excuses does not include sitting, having a picnic or sunbathing - evenyouaposre doing it with proper social distancing. Police have of course been asked to show discretion, and there are exceptions in the rules for people with a medical need. Can police go through my shopping  The law isnapost % clear - but the Home Secretary has said itaposs not appropriate. It comes after a police force threatened to go through peopleaposs bags to check for non-essential items. After an outcry, Northamptonshire Police later claried: We absolutely will NOT be searching peopleaposs shopping trolleys in Northamptonshire.Home Secretary Priti Patel later said this is not appropriate and branded it heavy-handed. So thataposs all good. But what does the law say  The law says you can go out to buy basic necessities, including food and medical supplies. So you might interpret that asyou start buying non-essential items, youaposre breaking the law. But the government also says open shops donapost have to pull all their non-essential items from stock. So Sainsburyaposs can carry on selling, say, kidsapos toys and paddling pools - and thereaposs nothing to stop you buying them. Shops that are still open are free to sell any items that they have in stock, Downing Street told us. Yet Downing Street also told us: When we ask the police to carry out enforcement of any rules we give them discretion on how to do that. Thataposs the nature of policing in the UK. They have set out in guidance to officers that they should engage, explain, encourage and then finally enforce.

title: voice mirror lockdown only bearable
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Lockdown only bearablewe can see light at end of the tunnelThe nation is doing its best to obey lockdown guidance but it needs reassurance on the governments plan for le toto normal after coronavirusShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  APR NewsopinionThe public needs to hear the plan for le after lockdown " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe country has embraced the coronavirus lockdown with fortitude. We have changed the way we live and work because we understand the importance of protecting the NHS and therefore saving lives. A stoic nation will continue to accept these restrictions for as long as is necessary. But they will also want reassurance that at some point le can start toto normal. So far the Government has failed to explain how the restrictions will be wound down. People understand the exact timetable will depend on how well social distancing works. The Government’s scientic advisers say that while the initial data is promising, it is too early to say for certain how effective it is. As a result, it is almost certain the lockdown will continue well beyond the Easter weekend. Parents want to know when children will be able toto school. Firms want guidance on how long they will have to remain closed and furlough staff. Families want to visit relatives again. The lockdown is only bearablepeople can see light at the end of the tunnel. Silver linings While the lockdown is an anxious time, it has brought out the best in people. Neighbours look out for each other and communities rally together. Another unexpected benefit is people embracing new ways of communicating.

title: coronavirus covid 19 not possible
story: NewsCoronavirus Covid- not possible to eliminate now despite lockdown, says expertLeading expert Professor David Heymann has issued a warning and says the "destiny" of coronavirus Covid- is not yet clear - he also spoke of cases where people have tested positive more than once for the diseaseShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsProfessor David Heymann led the global shutdown of the Sars outbreak in  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIt is not clearCovid- will become endemic, an infectious disease specialist has said. Professor David Heymann, a leading expert on infection outbreak control, said it is not possible to predict the destiny of a new infection. He said it is not viable yet to tell whether the new coronavirus will become endemic - or regularly found in society - like seasonal flu or HIV. The new coronavirus outbreak is on trajectory to continue transmitting for a time but it unclear whether it will be long term, he said. But he warned it may be that it canapost be eliminated as it is now. Do you have a coronavirus story  Email webnews@mirror Citing the situation in China, Prof Heymann, who led the global shutdown of the Sars outbreak in , said that despite severe lockdown measures the virus has not been eliminated. Despite their extreme measures they still have a little bit about - I think they had nine cases in one day recently, whereas in imported cases theyaposve had over  or  a day of cases being imported in Chinese coming back, etc, he told an online briefing with the think tank Chatham House. So, it would be nicethis could be eliminated. But it looks like - and weaposre watching very closely, whataposs happening in China - it looks like it hasnapost been eliminated from China.  If thataposs the case, under these severe lockdown measures, then it may be that it canapost be eliminated as it is now. We canapost really predict the destiny of a new and emerging infection. At present, we can only say that itaposs in populations now, and that it looks like itaposs on a trajectory to continue transmitting for a time, but we just donapost know what will happen in the long-term. We know that some influenza viruses enter human populations and transmit quite signicantly. And then they disappear. So you know itaposs not really clear that this virus will become endemic, as did HIV has some seasonal influenza.  But you know, every day, the chances are more and more that it may at least linger longer than we hope, and it may linger for a longer period and it may, as [some] predict, may linger indefinitely, but I canapost say that because I donapost have any evidence yet that that would occur. We have to just wait and see and do our best to control it. He was also asked about  patients in South Korea who had Covid-, tested negative for the virus after their recovery, and three weeks later tested as positive. Prof Heymann, who works for the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said scientists are working to determine whether these tests show reinfection, or recrudescence, or re-occurrence of the virus. To do that, theyaposre looking at the virus under a genetic sequencing analysis, to seethe virus that occurred two weeks or three weeks after PCR testing became negative in those persons is the same virus, which has reappeared which was hiding from the immune system previously, or whether that virus is a new virus, he said.

story: NewsCoronavirus doctors moving picture awaiting first patients at NHS NightingaleProfessor Richard Schilling, Deputy Clinical Director at the new COVID- hospital in east London, said he found the image of him "sad" and wished he didnt have to be thereShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsProfessor Richard Schilling, Deputy Clinical Director of the hospital, said he found the image sad and moving " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis image shows a coronavirus doctor waiting for the first patients to arrive at the new NHS nightingale hospital. Professor Richard Schilling is Deputy Clinical Director at the COVID- hospital in east London. He tweeted the image of him waiting at an entrance before the hospital started receiving its first patients yesterday. The cardiology specialist said: I find this photo of me waiting for our first patient both sad and moving. I wish we didn’t have to be here.Professor Schilling is one of thousands who have volunteered to work at the specialist coronavirus hospital build in Londonaposs enormous ExCel conference centre. Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog hereSimilar hospitals are in the pipeline across the UK, including in Cardf, Glasgow, Manchester, Harrogate and Bristol. A spokesperson for the NHS Nightingale said: Our first patients have now been admitted to the NHS Nightingale London, as planned. There is also treatment capacity available in other hospitals across London to complement the care being provided at the London Nightingale.  The NHS Nightingale confirmed on social media it was now operational and thanked other emergency services for their assistance in transporting patients.It wrote on  Twitter : This evening the @RoyalAirForce and @Ldn_Ambulance practiced a patient transfer. Speed and efficiency come naturally to our emergency responders #ThankYou for helping us to treat the people that need us, when they need us most.

title: double lung transplantee list goodbye
story: NewsDouble-lung transplantee has list of goodbye calls in case she gets coronavirusEXCLUSIVE: Justine Laymond, from Rayleigh, Essex, says she knows it will be "game over" for hershe gets coronavirus and is urging anyone thinking of breaking the lockdown to stay at homeShareCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsJustine says she knowsshe catches covid- it could be the end for her " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA double-lung transplantee who knows she will dieshe catches coronavirus has written a list of people sheaposll call to say goodbye to,an ambulance is called. Justine Laymond has a permanently compromised immune system following her le-saving transplant back in  and has one of the worldaposs rarest lung diseases. Speaking to , the -year-old said she knows that catching Covid- would be game over for her, but she is determined to do all she can to stay safe at home. And she is calling on everyone across the UK to do their bit this weekend and asks anyone thinking of breaking the lockdown to simply not do it. She said: The sun may be shining outside - but darkness will fall on others who may die,not yourself. This is not a movie, itaposs reality. Have you got a coronavirus story  Email webnews@mirror Justine was just hours from dying back in July  when she fought back from being in a three-week coma, spending weeks on le support and  lung collapses to be well enough to be put on the transplant list. Her le was eventually saved when she received the healthy lungs of a -year-old man, and she was given another chance at le. But Justine, who is currently furloughed from her part time job at Hyundai in Chelmsford, admits she is frightened for her health once again. But after spending two days crying over what the deadly virus could mean for her, Justine picked herself up and decided to fight for her le - by staying safe and self-isolating. She said: Iaposm so frightened. Iaposm not going out to exercise every day. I need to keep my fitness up so my lungs stay healthy. But I knowI do get it, I will die. I would fight for my leI did get it, but I know it will kill me. Justine, from Rayleigh, Essex added: Iaposve got my wishes written out. If we have to call an ambulance, Iaposve got a list of people to call to say goodbye to. Iaposve got an emergency bag packed. I knowI get this I will die, thataposs the reality.  Justine, who is self-isolating with partner Tom Hipperson, was left in shock when she was not included in the Governmentaposs list of .milllion people most at risk from the virus. Despite being a transplantee, permanently immuno-compromised and having serious underlying health conditions, she did not get a text to say she would have help getting the vital medicines she takes each day, or have any way of getting food. After numerous calls to her GP and hospital, she was eventually told her medical records were not accurate and her medical code needed amending so she could be included on the high risk list.  And now she is back to her positive self, doing fitness classes at home and keeping up her hobbies as a drag queen, where she has a large online presence, and keeping busy with cos-play make up and art. She said: I know Iaposm in lockdown for  weeks, so you just have to change your mindset.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A -year-old woman has become one of the oldest Brits to beat coronavirus after a  day fight.Great-grandmother Joyce Goldstraw, from Leek, Staffordshire, fell ill on March  - with her family despairing after she was then diagnosed with COVID-. Joyce, who worked as a corporal in the Women’s RAF during the Second World War, received treatment at Macclesfield General Hospital for a fortnight. Hospital measures to stem the spread of coronavirus meant no access could be granted to friends or family.Joyceaposs three children, six grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren were left anxiously waiting for updates, reports Stoke-on-Trent Live. Medics made sure hard-of-hearing Joyce was comfortable and receiving the appropriate care, but family wonderedthe virus, or the social distancing measures imposed by the Government, would prevent Joyce from ever ing home.Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog hereHowever, against all odds the near-centenarian made a miraculous recovery and ed home last week to her flat which she has occupied for more than  years, after tests showed Joyce had overcome the virus. Now Joyce, who also worked in several mills in Leek, is back at home watching re-runs of past sporting events - wondering why there’s no live snooker on TV, and asking relativesEngland striker Harry Kane has shaken off his injury problems. She is one of the oldest woman in the UK to have beaten coronavirus. Proud son John Goldstraw, who lives in Ipstones, said: “My mum has always been incredibly strong, but to have seen off the coronavirus is unbelievable.  “Mum was a corporal in the Women’s Royal Air Force during the Second World War - something she is incredibly proud of to this day - and perhaps it’s that fighting spirit that has seen her through this latest battle.” Eldest daughter Julie Poulson said:  “It’s brilliant to have mum home, we can’t thank the NHS staff enough.” Joyce was stationed at Tern Hill RAF airfield, in Shropshire, during the Second World War, working on Lancaster Bombers and Spitfire aircraft.  In later le she was a well-known face in many sports teams across the Staffordshire Moorlands, winning accolades in darts and crown green bowls teams from the s until the s.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA former World Health ­Organisation executive has revealed his four-step strategy to ease Britain out of coronavirus lockdown. Professor Karol Sikora said the first step would be to let small businesses with fewer than  staff open again on April . All schools should be allowed to reopen and social distancing measures should be eased on May , the ex-director of the UN bodyaposs cancer unit argued. Offices, bars and restaurants should be able to open their doors again on May , Prof Sikora, a former member of the Department of Healthaposs Expert Advisory Group on cancer, said. The final step ministers should take is easing restrictions on international travel and mass gatherings on June . The professor said: With more testing, no mutation of the virus and compliance with the rules I think this is a feasible timetable. He added: The lockdown is working - we are flattening the curve. But we need to see an exit strategy. With more testing, no mutation of the virus and compliance with the rules I think this is a feasible timetable. During this crisis I have remained an optimist- letaposs hope Iaposm right.  He said that his timeline was contingent on the virus peaking this weekend and people following the Governmentaposs rules.As ministers came under pressure to tell parents whether their children canto the classroom, Robert Halfon said he was worried some kids will be left behind because of the ongoing coronavirus lockdown.Health chiefs insist it is “premature” to say when the restrictions will be lted and they are likely to extend beyond next week.Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced the review of the ­lockdown will go ahead around Monday, more than three weeks after it was imposed, but refused to put a time on when an exit strategy will start. It is all but certain that schools will not be opening after the Easter break. But heads and MPs have said that, while it would be unsafe toin coming weeks, they would hope to be able to open fully before the end of the summer term in July.As the number of UK deaths rose by  to ,, Mr Halfon – chair of the Education Select Committee – said: “Obviously I want schools to open as soon as possible because I’m really worried about what’s going to happen toleft-behind kids. If they’re stuck at home they’re potentially going to suffer enormously.“Education is the most important thing we can give to children and young people and it’s vital that schools open as soon as the science allows. It has to be a number one priority for the Government.”  Mr Halfon spoke after review from University College London last week cast doubt on the effectiveness of school closures in halting the disease. But unions have stressed the safety of teachers, pupils and the community – must come first. Chris Keates, acting general secretary of the NASUWT, said: “Everyone is anxious toto normality as soon as possible, but decisions to either strengthen or loosen the current restrictions must always be governed by the medical and scientic evidence. Political or business considerations must never be allowed to override the safety of pupils, school staff and the wider community.” Whitehall sources insisted no date had been set to reopen schools in England, and that a date would only emerge once scientic advice concluded it was safe for them to do so. Mr Sunak said: “We committed there would be a review in and around three weeks, that review will be based on the evidence and data, which will only be ­available next week. I think rather than speculate about the future, I think we should focus ­seriously on the here and now.”The authorities face more immediate concerns over the four-day Easter weekend, with the expected warm weather prompting fears that parks and beaches will again be packed.Experts say any easing of social distancing measures relies on widespread testing - which Britain has fallen woefully behind on. Ministers are reportedly preparing to issue a plea to UK industry to build a home antibody test that would help exit the lockdown. Health Secretary Matt Hancock has promised , daily tests by the end of the month so that all stretched NHS staff who are self-isolating can be checked for the virus. The Department of Health said that a new testing laboratory set up by ­AstraZeneca, GSK and Cambridge University would aim to carry out , tests a day by May. It could take weeks before the ­slowdown in infections turns into a fall in daily deaths.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCoronavirus lockdown enforcers swooped on a tattoo studio - unaware it was being used as a base for a food bank to support struggling families. Jason Powner, , has been busy putting together food parcels to deliver to the elderly self-isolating due to Covid-. He uses his tattoo parlour, called SkinJase, as a hub to prepare parcels and as a drop-off point for donations, reports Stoke-on-Trent Live. But environmental officers from Stoke-on-Trent City Council yesterday carried out a spotcheck after receiving a tip-off the tattooist was still working. Do you have a coronavirus story to share  Email webnews@mirror  In a scathing post on Facebook, Jason, of Burslem, Stoke-on-Trent, described the tell-tale as a neanderthal. I just had a call from the Environmental Health and a visit from suits and clip board, the charity champion wrote. They said aposwe have received a couple of complaints from very worried members of the public that your still openapos. I replied that aposYes, thataposs right we are openapos. They then said aposOh can you tell me how your tattooing from the safe two-metre distance. I told them aposYes, of course I use a broom stick with f***ing duck tape at the end of it, not the best tattoos Iaposve done but gets me through these rough timesapos. I then went on and said aposI have a question for you, Iaposve been out of work like most for three weeks and still have not received a f***ing penny from the state after you closed us all down apos. I told them to aposPlease Google the name SkinjJase and youaposll find out why Iaposm openapos. I added aposnow please remove yourself from my studio and please tell the certain member of the public he sheaposs a neanderthalapos.  SkinJase is one of  businesses in Stoke-on-Trent which have been visited to censure they are complying with new legislation in the wake of the pandemic. In  instances, environmental health officers issued advice. But Jason, who has spent a decade helping families and charities across the city including raising hundreds of thousands of pounds for worthy causes, struggling families and poorly children, feels the council has been overzealous. He said: Apparently they received a complaint and it wouldnapost surprise meit was malicious. I know the council is just doing its job but Iaposm well-known for what I do in the community. If theyaposd just done a little bit of research and typed the name SkinJase into Google they would have saved themselves a trip. The coronavirus lockdown is a worrying time for millions across the UK. But itaposs also bringing out the best in people who are selflessly giving their time each day to help those most in need. Our Mirror Coronavirus Heroes series wants to recognise all of those helping the most vulnerable during the crisis. Whether itaposs a local business going the extra mile for the community or a teenager helping an elderly neighbour, we want to hear about it. You can email your stories of Mirror Coronavirus Heroes to webnews@mirror. I just wanted to get the word out that Iaposm not open for tattoos. Iaposve been doing the food bank now for six or seven years but since we went into lockdown, the workload has quadrupled. Weaposre mainly helping pensioners and the vulnerable who canapost get out due to self-isolation. We take along a weekaposs supply of shopping. Weaposve been all over Stoke-on-Trent. We must have visited  addresses in the last two weeks. Weaposve also been helping those that we normally support and weaposve donated to around a dozen care homes as theyaposre struggling too. I couldnapost do it without all the donations, the people of Stoke-on-Trent have been so generous. Iaposm just the middle man.

To mark Maundy Thursday, which commemorates the Last Supper, Jesusaposs final meal with his  disciples before he was killed, the Monarch hands out coins in a tradition that dates back to the th Century. Every year, the Queen attends a church service in Windsor and hands coins to senior citizens selected in recognition of the service they have given to the church and their local area. But despite the service being cancelled this year, she was determined that people would not miss out so has sent the pensioners a personal note and a minted coin the thank them for their hard work. The letter reads: I have great pleasure in sending you the Maundy Gt, which, unfortunately, I am unable to distribute to you personally at the Royal Maundy Service in St Georgeaposs Chapel, Windsor Castle, on Thursday, th April. This ancient Christian ceremony which reflects Jesusaposs instruction to his Disciples to love one another, is a call to the service of others, something that has been at the centre of my le. I believe it is a call to service for all of us.  It is one of my most rewarding duties as Sovereign to observe this highly signicant ceremony at such an important point in the Christian calendar. I know that you, as a Recipient of this yearaposs Maundy gt, will be as deeply disappointed as I am that it is not going ahead, while understanding the necessary decision in the current circumstances. However this shoud not mean your invaluable contribution within the community goes unnoticed, and I am sending this Maundy Gt to thank you for your Christian service. My thoughts and prayers are with you and your families at this dficult time. With my best wishes to you this Easter. The note is hand signed with Elizabeth R. Retired teacher Jane Armstrong was one of the pensioners to be sent her Maundy Money through the post after volunteering more than  years at her local church.  Jane, , of Bishop Auckland, County Durham, has run youth clubs, crisis support groups and food banks, at Woodhouse Close Church, sincethe late s. The Maundy Thursday service at Windsor would have been the third time she met the Queen. Her package from the Queen contained a £ coin commemorating William Wordsworth in a red pouch, a p coin for the  Olympics in a silver pouch. The  specially-minted silver pennies were in a white pouch. The married mum-of-two and grandmother-of-one said: “In the letter she expressed her sadness that it couldn’t go ahead. “I understand that she has never missed a service and that Maundy Thursday is very important to her as she has strong Christiancommitments.  “I think she is quite sad about it. It was way before Christmas I had the invitation. “I was surprised but itaposs quite an honour. I’m very committed to my work at the church and I felt it was important. I think it was for thework I do at the church. “All my le I’ve worked at the church. We are very involved in the community. “It’s been a privilege to be part of that. I’m still in and out every day even at my age. “We are still working during coronavirus and the food bank is open every day. “It would have been the third time I had met the Queen after I received my MBE in  and later a ceremony with the Queen for theChurch Urban Fund.
